turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: If you hadn't come along and protected me when you did, I'd have killed them fellows.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Go and get yourself washed up, Mr. Bernstein.  There doesn't seem to be an serious injury.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Not to me.  But you will let that cop go home with Mr. Kane, won't you?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Bernstein.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Leland.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Hello, Bernstein.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Where is it - where's my notice? I've got to finish it!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mr. Kane is finishing it.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Kane?  Charlie?  Where is he?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I suppose he's fixing it up - I know I'd never get that through.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mr. Kane is finishing your piece the way you started it.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Welcome, Mr. Kane, to the "Enquirer." I am Herbert Carter.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Thank you, Mr Carter.  This is Mr. Leland.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: How do you do, Mr. Leland?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Are they standing for me?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I thought it would be a nice gesture - the new publisher -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Ask them to sit down.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You may resume your work, gentlemen.  I didn't know your plans and so I was unable to make any preparations.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I don't my plans myself.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Mr. Carter, this is Mr. Bernstein. Mr. Bernstein is my general manager.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: How do you do, Mr. Bernstein?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You've got a private office here, haven't you?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: My little sanctum is at your disposal. But I don't think I understand -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm going to live right here.  As long as I have to.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: But a morning newspaper, Mr. Kane. After all, we're practically closed twelve hours a day - except for the business offices -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's one of the things I think must be changed, Mr. Carter.  The news goes on for twenty-four hours a day.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm not criticizing, Mr. Carter, but here's what I mean.  There's a front page story in the "Chronicle,"  and a picture - of a woman in Brooklyn who is missing.  Probably murdered.  A Mrs. Harry Silverstone.  Why didn't the "Enquirer" have that this morning?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Because we're running a newspaper, Mr. Kane, not a scandal sheet.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm still hungry, Brad.  Let's go to Rector's and get something decent.  The "Chronicle" has a two-column headline, Mr. Carter.  Why haven't we?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: There is no news big enough.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: If the headline is big enough, it makes the new big enough.  The murder of Mrs. Harry Silverstone -

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: As a matter of fact, we sent a man to the Silverstone home yesterday afternoon.  Our man even arrived before the "Chronicle" reporter.  And there's no proof that the woman was murdered - or even that she's dead.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: The "Chronicle" doesn't say she's murdered, Mr. Carter.  It says the neighbors are getting suspicious.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: It's not our function to report the gossip of housewives.  If we were interested in that kind of thing, Mr. Kane, we could fill the paper twice over daily -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's the kind of thing we are going to be interested in from now on, Mr. Carter.  Right now, I wish you'd send your best man up to see Mr. Silverstone.  Have him tell Mr. Silverstone if he doesn't produce his wife at once, the "Enquirer" will have him arrested.  Have him tell Mr. Silverstone he's a detective from the Central Office. If Mr. Silverstone asks to see his badge, your man is to get indignant and call Mr. Silverstone an anarchist. Loudly, so that the neighbors can hear.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Really, Mr. Kane, I can't see the function of a respectable newspaper -

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: But, Mr. Kane -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That'll be all today, Mr. Carter. You've been most understanding. Good day, Mr. Carter!

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I've been a newspaperman my whole life and I don't intend -  - if it's your intention that I should continue to be harassed by this - this -  I warn you, Mr. Kane, it would go against my grain to desert you when you need me so badly - but I would feel obliged to ask that my resignation be accepted.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It is accepted, Mr. Carter, with assurances of my deepest regard.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: But Mr. Kane, I meant -

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Mr. Kane, this is a surprise!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: We've got a nice plant here.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Was the show covered by every department?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Exactly according to your instructions, Mr. Kane.  We've got two spreads of pictures.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: And the notice?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Yes - Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Is it good?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Yes, Mr. kane.

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: But there's another one still to come - the dramatic notice.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It isn't finished?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: No, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's Leland, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Has he said when he'll finish?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: We haven't heard from him.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: He used to work fast - didn't he, Mr. Bernstein?

turns.speaker: DR. COREY
turns.text: The nurse has complete instructions, but if you care to talk to me at any time, I should be only too glad -  I shall be here in the morning.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Thank you.  I can't imagine how Mrs. Kane came to make such a silly mistake.  The sedative Dr. Wagner gave her is in a somewhat larger bottle -  I suppose the strain of preparing for her trip has excited and confused her.

turns.speaker: DR. COREY
turns.text: I'm sure that's it.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: There are no objections to my staying here with her, are there?

turns.speaker: DR. COREY
turns.text: Not at all.  I'd like the nurse to be here, too.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: How do you do?  I came here - and I made Mr. Kane come with me...  because I recieved this note -

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: I made Miss - Miss Alexander send you the note.  She was a little unwilling at first -  but she did it.

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: Maybe you can do it and maybe you can't, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Charles!  Your - your breaking this man's neck -  would scarcely explain this note -  Serious consequences for Mr. Kane -  for myself, and for my son.  What does this note mean, Miss -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Let him finish, Charles.

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: I'm protecting myself every way I know how, Mrs. Kane.  This last week, I finally found out how I can stop your husband from being elected. If the people of this state learn what I found out this week, he wouldn't have a chance to - he couldn't be elected Dog Catcher.  Well, what I'm interested in is seeing that he's not elected.  I don't care whether they know what I know about him.  Let him keep right on being the Great, Noble, Moral -  Champeen of the people.  Just as long as -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I think I understand, Mr. Rogers, but I wonder if -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: What story, Mr. Rogers?

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: The story about him and Miss Alexander, Mrs. Kane.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: You don't have to show me anything, Mr. Rogers.  I believe you.

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: I'd rather Mr. Kane withdrew without having to get the story published. Not that I care about him.  But I'd be better off that way -  - and so would you, Mrs. Kane.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Hello, Brad -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Emily -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I'm sorry I sent for you, Brad - I didn't -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Chicago is pretty close to New York nowadays - only twenty hours -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Almost two to one -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I'm surprised he got the votes he did.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Emily!

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Why should anyone vote for him? He's made it quite clear to the people what he thinks of them. Children - to be told one thing one day, something else the next, as the whim seizes him.  And they're supposed to be grateful and love and adore him - because he sees to it that they get cheap ice and only pay a nickel in the street cars.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Emily, you're being - a little unfair -  You know what I think of Charles' behavior - about your personal lives -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: There aren't any personal lives for people like us.  He made that very clear to me nine years ago - If I'd thought of my life with Charles as a personal life, I'd have left him then -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I know that, Emily -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Maybe I should have - the first time he showed me what a mad dog he really was.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Emily, you -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Brad, I'm -  I'm not an old woman yet -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: It's - all over -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I know it is, Brad -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: He's paying for it, Emily.  Those returns tonight - he's finished. Politically -  - socially, everywhere, I guess. I don't know about the papers, but -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: If you're asking me to sympathize with him, Brad, you're wasting your time.  There's only one person I'm sorry for, as a matter of fact.  That - that shabby little girl.  I'm really sorry for her, Brad.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What do you expect me to do?  What in the world -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Charles.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: They won't do anything to Junior, darling.  Anonymous letter writers -   I've got guards in front of the house, and I'm going to arrange -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Please don't talk any more, Charles.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Have they heard from father yet? Has he seen -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I've tried to tell you, Emily. The President's going to be all right.  He had a comfortable night. There's no danger of any kind.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Here I am, darling...  Darling!... Darling, it's all right...  Mother's here.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Emily - you musn't leave me now - you can't do that to me.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: They won't hurt you, darling. Mother's with you!  Mother's looking after you!

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I'm sending Junior home in the car, Charles - with Oliver -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: But I'd arranged to go home with you myself.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: There's a call I want you to make with me, Charles.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It can wait.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: No, it can't.  Good night, darling.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What's this all about, Emily?  I've had a very tiring day and -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: It may not be about anything at all.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I intend to find out.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I insist on being told exactly what you have in mind.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I'm going to -  - 185 West 74th Street.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Oh!!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're a cheap, crooked grafter - and your concern for your children and your mother -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You don't think I'm going to let this blackmailer intimidate me, do you?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I don't see what else you can do, Charles.  If he's right - and the papers publish this story he has -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Oh, they'll publish it all right. But that's not going to stop me -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Charles, this - this story - doesn't concern only you.  I'll be in it, too, won't I?  And Junior?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I suppose so, but - I'm not afraid of the story.  You can't tell me that the voters of this state -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I'm not interested in the voters of this state right now.  I am interested in - well, Junior, for one thing.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Oh yes, there is.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I don't think so.  Are you coming, Charles?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: There's only one person in the world to decide what I'm going to do - and that's me.  And if you think - if any of you think -

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: You decided what you were going to do, Charles - some time ago.  You can't always have it your own way, regardless of anything else that may have happened.  Come on, Charles.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Go on!  Get out!  I can fight this thing all alone!

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Charles, if you don't listen to reason, it may be too late -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Too late for what?  Too late for you and this -  this public thief to take the love of the people of this state away from me?  Well, you won't do it, I tell you.  You won't do it!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I can't tell you the things he said, Charlie.  You haven't got any idea -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Rogers, I don't think I will postpone doing something about you until I'm elected.  To start with, I'll break your neck.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You can't blackmail me, Rogers, you can't -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Charlie, he said, unless you withdrew your name -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Charlie, you're just excited.  You don't realize -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I know exactly what I'm doing.  Get out!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Get out, both of you!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Charlie, please don't -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What are you waiting here for? Why don't you go?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Ow!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Toothache.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Hmm!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You've got some on your face.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: If these sidewalks were kept in condition - instead of the money going to some cheap grafter -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What's funny now?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You are.  You look like you've been making mud pies.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're no Venus de Milo.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: If you want to come in and wash your face -  I can get you some hot water to get that dirt off your trousers -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Hey, you should be more careful. That's my ma and pa.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  They live here, too?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No.  They've passed on.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Where's the soap?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: In the water.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're very easily amused.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I always like to see the funny side of things.  No sense crying when you don't have to.  And you're so funny.  Looking at you, I forget all about my toothache.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I can't stay here all night chasing your pain away.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I know...  But you do look so silly.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Where's the towel?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: On the chiffonier.  Here.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I've got a brush in the closet.  As soon as the mud on your trousers is all dry - you just brush it off.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'll get these streets fixed, if it's the last thing I do.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: A chicken?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: No.  But you're close.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: A rooster?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're getting farther away all the time.  It's a duck.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Excuse me, Mr. Kane.  I know this takes a lot of nerve, but - who are you?  I mean - I'm pretty ignorant, I guess you caught on to that -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You really don't know who I am?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No.  That is, I bet it turns out I've heard your name a million times, only you know how it is -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: But you like me, don't you?  Even though you don't know who I am?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You've been wonderful!  I can't tell you how glad I am you're here, I don't know many people and -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: And I know too many people.  Obviously, we're both lonely.  Would you like to know where I was going tonight - when you ran into me and ruined my Sunday clothes?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I didn't run into you and I bet they're not your Sunday clothes. You've probably got a lot of clothes.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I was only joking!  This evening I was on my way to the Western Manhattan Warehouses - in search of my youth.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Who am I?  Well, let's see.  Charles Foster Kane was born in New Salem, Colorado in eighteen six -  I run a couple of newspapers.  How about you?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, me -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: How old did you say you were?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I didn't say.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I didn't think you did.  If you had, I wouldn't have asked you again, because I'd have remembered. How old?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Pretty old.  I'll be twenty-two in August.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's a ripe old age -  What do you do?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I work at Seligman's.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Is that what you want to do?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I want to be a singer.  I mean, I didn't.  Mother did for me.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What happened to the singing? You're not in a show, are you?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, no!  Nothing like that.  Mother always thought - she used to talk about Grand Opera for me.  Imagine! An American girl, for one thing - and then my voice isn't really that kind anyway, it's just that Mother - you know what mothers are like.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Yes -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I do sing a little.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Would you sing for me?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, you wouldn't want to hear me sing.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Yes, I would.  That's why I asked.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well, I -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Don't tell me your toothache is bothering you again?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, no, that's all gone.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Then you have no alibi at all. Please sing.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I couldn't make you see how I felt, Charlie.  I just couldn't -  I couldn't go threw with singing again. You don't know what it means to feel - to know that people - that an audience don't want you.  That if you haven't got what they want - a real voice - they just don't care about you.  Even when they're polite - and they don't laugh or get restless or - you know... They don't want you.  They just 0

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's when you've got to fight them. That's when you've got to make them. That's -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Charlie!  I said, what time is it?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Half past eleven.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I mean in New York.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Half past eleven.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: At night?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Yes.  The bulldog's just gone to press.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Hurray for the bulldog!  Half past eleven!  The shows have just let out.  People are going to night clubs and restaurants.  Of course, we're different.  We live in a palace - at the end of the world.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You always said you wanted to live in a palace.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Can't we go back, Charlie?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It makes a whole lot more sense than collecting Venuses.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You may be right -  I sometimes wonder - but you get into the habit -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It's not a habit.  I do it because I like it.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I was referring to myself.  I thought we might have a picnic tomorrow - it might be a nice change after the Wild West party tonight.  Invite everybody to go to the Everglades -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Invite everybody!  Order everybody, you mean, and make them sleep in tents!  Who wants to sleep in tents when they have a nice room of their own - with their own bath, where they know where everything is?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I mean it.  Oh, I know I always say I mean it, and then I don't - or you get me so I don't do what I say I'm going to - but -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're in a tent, darling.  You're not at home.  And I can hear you very well if you just talk in a normal tone of voice.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm not going to have my guests insulted, just because you think -  - if people want to bring a drink or two along on a picnic, that's their business.  You've got no right -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I've got more than a right as far as you're concerned, Susan.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, I'm sick and tired of you telling me what I must and what I musn't do!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're my wife, Susan, and -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm not just your wife, I'm a person all by myself - or I ought to be.  I was once.  Sometimes you get me to believing I never was.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: We can discuss all this some other time, Susan.  Right now -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'll discuss what's on my mind when I want to.  You're not going to keep on running my life the way you want it.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: As far as you're concerned, Susan, I've never wanted anything -  I don't want anything now - except what you want.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What you want me to want, you mean. What you've decided I ought to have - what you'd want if you were me. But you've never given me anything that -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Susan, I really think -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, I don't mean the things you've given me - that don't mean anything to you.  What's the difference between giving me a bracelet or giving somebody else a hundred thousand dollars for a statue you're going to keep crated up and never look at?  It's only money.  It doesn't mean anything. You're not really giving anything that belongs to you, that you care about.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Susan, I want you to stop this. And right now!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well, I'm not going to stop it.  I'm going to say exactly what I think.  You've never given me anything.  You've tried to buy me into giving you something.  You're -  - it's like you were bribing me!  That's what it's been from the first moment I met you.  No matter how much it cost you - your time, your money - that's what you've done with everybody you've ever known.  Tried to bribe them!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Susan!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're talking an incredible amount of nonsense, Susan.  Whatever I do -  I do - because I love you.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Love!  You don't love anybody!  Me or anybody else!  You want to be loved - that's all you want!  I'm Charles Foster Kane.  Whatever you want - just name it and it's yours! Only love me!  Don't expect me to love you -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You'll never have another chance to hit me again.  I never knew till this minute -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Susan, it seems to me -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Don't tell me you're sorry.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm not sorry.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm going to leave you.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: No, you're not.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Don't you realize that everybody here is going to know about this? That you've packed your bags and ordered the car and -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: - And left?  Of course they'll hear.  I'm not saying goodbye - except to you - but I never imagined that people wouldn't know.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I won't let you go.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You can't stop me.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Goodbye, Charlie.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Don't go, Susan.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Let's not start all over again, Charlie.  We've said everything that can be said.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Susan, don't go!  Susan, please!

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: She doesn't know, Mrs. Kane.  She just sent it - because I made her see it wouldn't be smart for her not to send it.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: In case you don't know, Emily, this - this gentleman -  is -

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: I'm not a gentleman, Mrs. Kane, and your husband is just trying to be funny calling me one.  I don't even know what a gentleman is.  You see, my idea of a gentleman, Mrs. Kane - well, if I owned a newspaper and if I didn't like the way somebody else was doing things - some politican, say - I'd fight them with everything I had.  Only I wouldn't show him in a convict suit, with stripes - so his children could see the picture in the paper.  Or his mother.  It's pretty clear - I'm not a gentleman.

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: Anything you say, Mr. Kane.  Only we're talking now about what you are.  That's what the note is about, Mrs. Kane.  Now I'm going to lay all my cards on the table.  I'm fighting for my life.  Not just my political life.  My life.  If your husband is elected governor -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm going to be elected governor. And the first thing I'm going to do -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You do anything you want to do. The people of this state can decide which one of us to trust.  If you want to know, they've already decided. The election Tuesday'll be only -

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: Mrs. Kane, I'm not asking you to believe me.  I'd like to show you -

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: You're making a bigger fool of yourself than I thought you would, Mr. Kane.  You're licked.  Why don't you -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Get out!  I've got nothing to talk to you about.  If you want to see me, have the Warden write me a letter.

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: I see!

turns.speaker: ROGERS
turns.text: You're the greatest fool I've ever known, Kane.  If it was anybody else, I'd say what's going to happen to you would be a lesson to you.  Only you're going to need more than one lesson. And you're going to get more than one lesson.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Don't you worry about me.  I'm Charles Foster Kane.  I'm no cheap, crooked politician, trying to save himself from the consequences of his crimes -

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: It is the unanimous opinion of my Cabinent - in which I concur - that the proposed leases are in the best interests of the Governement and the people.  You are not, I hope, suggesting that these interests are not indentical?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm not suggesting anything, Mr. President!  I've come here to tell you that, unless some action is taken promptly - and you are the only one who can take it - the oil that is the property of the people of this country will be turned over for a song to a gang of high-pressure crooks!

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: I must refuse to allow you to continue in this vein, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It's the only vein I know.  I tell the facts the way I see them.  And any man that knows that facts -

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: I know the facts, Mr. Kane.  And I happen to have the incredible insolence to differ with you as to what they mean.  You're a man of great talents, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: I understand that you have political ambitions.  Unfortunately, you seem incapable of allowing any other opinion but your own -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'm much obliged, Mr. President, for your concern about me.  However, I happen to be concerned at this moment with the matter of extensive oil lands belonging to the people of the United States, and I say that if this lease goes through, the property of the people of the United States goes into the hands of -

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: You've made your point perfectly clear, Mr. Kane.  Good day.

turns.speaker: MATISTI
turns.text: Impossible!  Impossible!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Your job isn't to give Mrs. Kane your opinion of her talents. You're supposed to train her voice. Nothing more.

turns.speaker: MATISTI
turns.text: But, it is impossible.  I will be the laughingstock of the musical world!  People will say -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: If you're interested in what people say, Signor Matisti, I may be able to enlighten you a bit.  The newspapers, for instance.  I'm an authority on what the papers will say, Signor Matisti, because I own eight of them between here and San Francisco...  It's all right, dear. Signor Matisti is going to listen to reason.  Aren't you, maestro?

turns.speaker: MATISTI
turns.text: Mr. Kane, how can I persuade you -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You can't.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You goin', Mom?

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: Your mother won't be going right away, Charles -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Where'm I going?

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: Is that really your idea of how to run a newspaper?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I don't know how to run a newspaper, Mr. Thatcher.  I just try everything I can think of.

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: "Enemy Armada Off Jersey Coast."  You know you haven't the slightest proof that this - this armada - is off the Jersey Coast.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Can you prove it isn't?

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: You see!  There hasn't been a true word -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I think we'll have to send our friend Wheeler a cable, Mr. Bernstein.  Of course, we'll have to make it shorter than his, because he's working on an expense account and we're not.  Let me see -  Mike!

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: I came to see you, Charles, about your - about the Enquirer's campaign against the Metropolitan Transfer Company.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Won't you step into my office, Mr. Thatcher?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Mr. Thatcher, isn't everything I've been saying in the Enquirer about the traction trust absolutely true?

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: They're all part of your general attack - your senseless attack - on everything and everybody who's got more than ten cents in his pocket. They're -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: The trouble is, Mr. Thatcher, you don't realize you're talking to two people.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: As Charles Foster Kane, who has 			eighty- two thousand, six hundred and thirty-one shares of Metropolitan Transfer - you see, I do have a rough idea of my holdings - I sympathize with you.  Charles Foster Kane is a dangerous scoundrel, his paper should be run out of town and a committee should be formed to boycott him.  You may, if you can form such a committee, put me down for a contribution of one thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: Charles, my time is too valuable for me -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: On the other hand -  I am the publisher of the Enquirer. As such, it is my duty - I'll let you in on a little secret, it is also my pleasure - to see to it that decent, hard-working people of this city are not robbed blind by a group of money- mad pirates because, God help them, they have no one to look after their interests!  I'll let you in on another little secret, Mr. Thatcher.  I think I'm the man to do it.  You see, I have money and property -

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: I happened to see your consolidated statement yesterday, Charles.  Could I not suggest to you that it is unwise for you to continue this philanthropic enterprise -  this Enquirer - that is costing you one million dollars a year?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're right.  We did lose a million dollars last year.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Get Dr. Corey.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Mrs. Kane would like to see you, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Is Mrs. Kane -

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Marie has been packing since morning, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Close the door, Raymond.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Lock it - and keep it locked.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Raymond -

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yes, sir -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Do you like poetry, Raymond?

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Can't say, sir.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Mrs. Kane liked poetry -

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Not my wife - not either of them.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Oh, yes, sir.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Do you know what that is?

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: It's a wall you bought in China, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Persia.  It belonged to a king.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: How did you get him to part with it, Mr. Kane?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: He was dead...  That's a poem.  Do you know what it means?

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: No, I don't, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I didn't used to be afraid of it.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Poor Mr. Carter!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What makes those fellows think that a newspaper is something rigid, something inflexible, that people are supposed to pay two cents for -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Tired?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: It's been a tough day.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: A wasted day.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I've changed the front page a little, Mr. Bernstein.  That's not enough - There's something I've got to get into this paper besides pictures and print -  I've got to make the "New York Enquirer" as important to New York as the gas in that light.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: What're you going to do, Charlie?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: That's the second sentence you've started with "I" -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: People are going to know who's responsible.  And they're going to get the news - the true news - quickly and simply and entertainingly.  And no special interests will be allowed to interfere with the truth of that news.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: The "Chronicle" is a good newspaper.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It's a good idea for a newspaper.  Four hundred sixy thousand.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Well, gentlemen, are we going to war?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Our readers are, anyway, I don't know about the rest of the country.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It'll be our first foreign war in fifty years, Brad.  We'll cover it the way the "Hickville Gazette" covers the church social!  The names of everybody there; what they wore; what they ate; who won the prizes; who gave the prizes -  I tell you, Brad, I envy you.  By Bradford Leland, the "Enquirer's" Special Correspondent at the Front. I'm almost tempted -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: But there is no Front, Charlie. There's a very doubtful civil war. Besides, I don't want the job.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: All right, Brad, all right - you don't have to be a war correspondent unless you want to - I'd want to.  Hello, Georgie.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charles, I tell you there is no war! There's a condition that should be remedied - but between that and a -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: How would the "Enquirer" look with no news about this non-existent war - with Benton, Pulitzer and Heart devoting twenty columns a day to it?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: They do it only because you do!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: And I do it because they do it, and they do it - it's a vicious circle, isn't it?  I'm going over to Georgie's, Brad - you know, Georgie, don't you?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Say, Brad.  I've got an idea.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I mean I've got a job for you.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You don't want to be a war correspondent - how about being a dramatic critic?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I'd like that.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You start tomorrow night.  Richard Carl in "The Spring Chicken."  I'll get us some girls.  You get tickets.  A drama critic gets them free, you know.  Rector's at seven?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charlie -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: It doesn't make any difference about me, but one of these days you're going to find out that all this charm of yours won't be enough -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're wrong.  It does make a difference to you -  Rector's, Brad?  Come to think of it, I don't blame you for not wanting to be a war correspondent.  You won't miss anything.  It isn't much of a war. Besides, they tell me there isn't a decent restaurant on the whole island.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Take dictation -  Front page editorial -  "This afternoon a great man was assassinated.  He was the President of the United States -"

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charlie -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Do you think you're the one who should call him a great man?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Why not?  Well - nobody's a great man in your estimation until he's dead.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What do you mean by that?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Yesterday morning you called the President a traitor.  What do you think that crowd is doing down there?  They think you murdered him.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Because the crackpot who did it had a copy of the "Enquirer" in his pocket?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: - and that copy of the "Enquirer" said the President should be killed.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I said treason was a capital offense punishable by death -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: You've said a lot of things about the President in the last few months.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: They're true!  Everything I said! Witholding that veto was treason!

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charlie!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Oil belonging to the people of the United States was leased out for a song to a gang of high-pressure crooks -  Nobody can blame me because -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Look out that window.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: There are the people of the United States, and they are blaming you - Oh, I know it doesn't make any sense, but at least you can learn a lesson from it.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What lesson?  Not to expose fraud when I see it?  Not to fight for the right of the people to own their own property?  Run it the way I said, Reilly - "This afternoon a great man was assassinated -"

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charlie!  Now you're not making sense.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I don't have to.  I run a newspaper with half a million readers and they're getting a martyred president this morning with their breakfast. I can't help that.  Besides, they all know I'm married to his niece.  I've got to think of her.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I've got to think of Emily -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I'd like to talk to you about that.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: First of all -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What's wrong, Brad?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I'm drunk.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'll get you some coffee.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: First of all, I will not write a good review of a play because somebody paid a thousand dollars for an advertisement in the "Enquirer."

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's just a little promotion scheme. Nobody expects you -  Mike, will you try and get Mr. Leland some coffee?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charlie, it's just no go.  We can't agree anymore.  I wish you'd let me go to Chicago.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Why, Brad?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I want to be transferred to the new paper.  You've been saying yourself you wish you had somebody to -  That's not what I wanted to talk about.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'll tell you what I'll do, Brad - I'll get drunk, too - maybe that'll help.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: No, that won't help.  Besides, you never get drunk.  I wanted to talk about you and Emily.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: She's going to leave you -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I don't think so, Brad.  We've just had word that the President is out of danger.  It seems I didn't kill him after all.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: She was going to leave you anyway -
